Award.AwardTitle: Multiscale, multimodal optical investigation of long-term, injury-induced alterations in neurovascular coupling

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
This proposal will work on identifying non-invasive markers for traumatic brain injury (TBI). The proposal lays out a plan to verify quantitative biomarkers for mild (m)TBI that persist in the weeks following an injury. The proposed research will partner with faculty and postdocs at the New York Medical College, the University of Colorado, the University of Pennsylvania, and the FDA. The proposal includes a well-designed mentoring plan to be implemented by the PI. The plan includes tracking progress through Individual Development Plans; informal discussions to assess satisfaction with the mentoring program' and tracking progress toward career goals.

The principal investigator will evaluate diffuse correlation spectroscopy as a noninvasive optical method for monitoring real-time changes in cerebral blood flow, in order to better inform medical interventions in the event of neurological injury or disease. This project will provide information on the types of changes that can be interrogated using the low-resolution diffuse correlation spectroscopy (DCS) technique. Direct comparison to a high resolution technique will provide necessary information on sensitivity and specificity for DCS. The use of stimulated changes during monitoring will provide the types of necessary detail on the populations of blood vessels that can be assessed. Cerebral blood flow can be used to inform medical interventions in cases of neurological injury or disease.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Traumatic brain injury (TBI) is a leading cause of death and disability in the U.S. The majority of these injuries are classified as "mild" TBI (mTBI), also known as "concussion," which can lead to temporary or permanent impairment of cognition, physical function, and psychosocial behavior. Among many open questions, one aspect of mTBI that remains particularly puzzling is the physiology of long-term changes in brain function. In particular, one repercussion of TBI is an ensuing mismatch between oxygen supply and neural metabolic demand. This relationship is termed the "neurovascular unit," and represents a fundamental dynamic coupling between neurons and nearby blood vessels. Damage to any portion of the cerebral vasculature fundamentally alters the ability of the network to supply neurons with energy.

We had previously found that in terms of electrical activity, it is the communication between different regions of the cerebral cortex, so-called "cortico-cortical" activity, that recovers the slowest after a head injury. It is precisely this communication between neurons at the primary sites of sensory evoked responses and those at more distant brain regions that constitutes the basis for interpreting the world around us. However, changes in neural electrical activity are difficult monitor over time for practical purposes. Optical methods for tracking blood flow in the brain, in contrast, offer more practical alternatives for assessing progress during recovery from a head injury. Can these noninvasive optical techniques be used to extract information regarding the spatial scale of changes in neural activity?

We looked at correlations between flow in vessels of different diameters in the cerebral cortex and the components of evoked neural activity putatively reflecting local and more distant brain regions. We were able to obtain evidence that the small vessel signal (thus likely associated with neural electrical activity in regions close to the initial sensory representation) recovered fairly quickly, whereas blood flow changes in putatively larger-diameter vessels recovered more slowly, and was likely most representative of longer-range electrical communication. Overall, our multimodal measurements permitted us to obtain a more nuanced understanding of how neuronal electrical activity and recruited blood flow co-vary during recovery from brain injury. These results can inform the review of future medical devices that use blood flow metrics to assess the efficacy of rehabilitation.

More broadly, in terms of education beyond the graduate level, while there exists a wide range of initiatives designed to encourage youth to enter into careers in science, technology, engineering and mathematics, there are few opportunities for young scientists--who have already chosen to pursue science at a high level--to expand the impact that they can have among sectors beyond academia. Funding from this award was able to facilitate a unique scientific research experience at the FDA, which combines an academic research approach with scientific issues of national interest.
